conclusion: Problem involves transverse harmonic wave along x-axis with amplitude A=10cm in two figures.
Figure 1 shows waveform at t=2s, Figure 2 shows particle vibration at x=2m.
Task is to find direction of wave propagation and wave speed.
Figure 1 is a snapshot of wave at t=2s, plot of displacement (y) vs position (x).
Figure 2 is a vibration diagram for particle at x=2m, showing displacement over time.
Figure 1 shows sine-like wave with crests and troughs, x-axis in meters from 0 to 6, y-axis displacement from -10cm to 10cm.
Figure 2 shows sine-like variation with time, y-axis displacement, x-axis time in seconds from 0 to 6.
Wavelength (λ) from Figure 1 is 4 meters, as distance between consecutive crests or troughs.
Period (T) from Figure 2 is 2 seconds, as time between two consecutive crests or troughs.
Wave speed (v) calculated as v = λ / T = 4 meters / 2 seconds = 2 meters/second.
Need to determine direction of wave propagation using phase relationship.
At t=2 seconds, particle at x=2 meters is at positive amplitude in Figure 2.
At t=2 seconds, particle at x=2 meters is at positive amplitude in Figure 1.
Consider right-hand rule or phase of wave for direction determination.
Wave equation: y(x,t) = A sin(kx - ωt + φ).
Wave number k = 2π/λ, angular frequency ω = 2π/T.
At t=2 seconds, argument of sine function for wave moving in +x direction is (k*2 - ω*2).
